title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003." It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new clause for nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical information on alien smuggling organizations and are essential to criminal investigations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include provisions for the successful prosecution of individuals involved in alien smuggling organizations and limiting the number of nonimmigrant visas for aliens with critical information on such organizations. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows officials to take lawful action to protect nonimmigrants and their family members. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the adjustment of status of a nonimmigrant to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence under certain conditions related to alien smuggling investigations. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the adjustment of status of a nonimmigrant to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence under specific conditions, including protection of identity if necessary. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase criminal penalties for bringing aliens into the US illegally, with potential 10-year sentence enhancements for certain criteria. Additionally, a rewards program is established to combat commercial alien smuggling. A rewards program is established to combat commercial alien smuggling involving the transportation of aliens in groups of 10 or more in a dangerous manner or posing a health risk. The program will be administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, with rewards authorized for individuals providing information leading to arrests or convictions related to such smuggling activities. A rewards program is established to combat commercial alien smuggling involving the transportation of aliens in groups of 10 or more in a dangerous manner or posing a health risk. Rewards are authorized for information leading to arrests, convictions, prevention, or dismantling of smuggling organizations. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out the rewards program. Government officials providing information while on duty are ineligible for rewards. Measures are in place to protect the identities of individuals providing information. There are limitations on the maximum reward amount. The rewards program authorizes a maximum reward of $100,000, with exceptions approved by the Secretary of Homeland Security for combating alien smuggling operations endangering lives or posing health risks. Rewards exceeding $50,000 require personal approval by the Secretary, and all rewards must be certified for payment by the Secretary. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with other relevant departments, will develop an outreach program to educate the public about penalties for harboring aliens and incentives for assisting in combating smuggling operations.
